newsitem.title: USA: Rubin reiterates strong dollar policy still holds.
newsitem.headline: Rubin reiterates strong dollar policy still holds.

text.p: U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin on Wednesday reiterated his support for a strong dollar, but declined comment on the currency's sharp recent fall in foreign exchange markets.
"A strong dollar has been our policy since the beginning of the (Clinton) administration. It's still our policy," Rubin said.
Asked by reporters if the dollar was currently strong, Rubin declined to comment.
"I'd really just like to stick with what I said," Rubin said.
Rubin also reiterated the benefits of a strong dollar for the U.S. economy.
"A strong dollar is in our interests. It leads to lower interest rates, lower inflation and it's obviously good for our economy," Rubin said.
Rubin declined comment on the Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates steady at a policy meeting on Tuesday, but noted that the economy remains on a solid footing.
"As long as we keep on a path of fiscal responsibility ... by far and away the most likely set of circumstances going forward is solid growth and low inflation," he said.
